Posts.Title: Bimmer & Diane Pix nowheregirl MargaretB

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 06:40PM MargaretB wrote: You will go through a lot of emotions so buckle in and hang on.  Even though cancer was discovered in one breast, I had a bilateral with immediate free-tram reconstruction and have had no regrets.  Because my sister had been diagnosed with BC at a young age, I was aware of my options.  Now that over 3 years has passed since my surgery, I recently decided to have genetic counseling and tested positive for BRCA2. At the time of my surgery, the tumor board drs. discovered calcifications in my left breast.  In hindsight, I could possibly be looking at a recurrence of BC so I feel I made the right decision for me.  It is a personal decision and one that you have to be comfortable with.  Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 03:41PM MargaretB wrote: Stephanie, glad you are doing well.  I had a hysterectomy, oopherectomy and bunionectomy 6 weeks ago, all on the same day.  Doing well and going back to work tomorrow after recovering at home.
Posts.Title: Ovaries removed tommorrow -Scared Stefanie MargaretB

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 06:03AM MargaretB wrote: I had a bilateral even though cancer was discovered in one breast.  I had a sister and mother who both had BC, the drs. had discovered calcifications of interest in the left breast, and I would have had to have a reduction anyway in the left breast.  The decision to have a bilateral was easier for me than the decision to have chemo but I did it and have not regretted it at all.  Like reconstruction, it is a very personal decision.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy-your input wanted tweekerbeeker lilith

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 08:26PM MargaretB wrote: My dx was confirmed with a meeting of the tumor board.  I knew the onc I wanted because a girlfriend of mine had used him.  He also happened to be at the tumor board meeting.  My BS was recommended by the radiologist and he worked in conjunction with my PS.  I was not that impressed with my BS's bedside manner but loved my onc and PS.  I figured I'd only see the BS once or twice so the other two were my main considerations.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 06:32AM MargaretB wrote: I just had the genetic testing done and got my results back Friday.  I am BRCA2.  I have already had a bilateral - after dx they saw calcification in the other breast that they weren't worried about "now" but I would have had to have a breast reduction anyway so that made my decision easier.  I had already planned to have my ovaries removed because of the risk relationship between ovarian and breast cancer but my test results decided it.  My sister, who was dx with BC at age 38, just had a total hysterectomy/ooph because pre-cancerous cells were found and she has had problems for a few months now.  She decided that enough was enough.  Good luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 08:51PM MargaretB wrote: I had the genetic test done yesterday.  I was told that because I had a dx before age 50 and a first degree relative (sis) had a dx before 40, it would automatically be covered.  I had already decided to have my ovaries removed because of the increased risk of ovarian cancer - I have a friend who is in her 30's going through a recurrence of ovarian cancer and it's not pretty.  I have a son and decided to do the genetic test because of his increased risk for male BC and prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2008 04:09PM MargaretB wrote: I have a mother and sister who had bc and now my husband has had squamous cell cancer on his ear; his father also had skin cancer. I decided to have it done to see if the mutation ended with me or if my son would have to worry about prostate cancer more than his peers. I did see the counselor and felt very comfortable with him; the most it will cost me out of pocke is $300 but in all likelihood it will cost me the cost of a copay.  I got my results back late last week and I do have a BRCA 2 mutation.  Good luck in making your decision.
